title-group.article-title: Bartók's Non-Classical Narrative: Sonata for Violin and Piano, No. 2 (1922)

abstract.p: In spite of its classical framework, the inner directions and the narrative of Bartók's music are unconventional; they are unusual even in the context of twentieth-century music. By inner direction and narrative I mean those features of the music that determine the flow of the musical process, such as: balance between static and dynamic sections, distribution of thematic and transitional materials, proportions, development toward climax and the placing of climaxes, the logic in the sequence of musical character, strategies for opening and ending a composition, and so on. In these aspects, Bartók's forms are deeply alien to Classical and, for the most part, even to Romantic thinking.
